G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 21..proposition: This is a civil action for negligence seeking monetary damages in an amount within the jurisdiction of this Court, pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 21.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Brockton District Court under G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the Defendant has a usual place of business in this county and the cause of action arose here.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3..proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper because Defendant resides in, maintains a usual place of business in, and conducts substantial activities within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions alleged herein occurred within this Commonwealth. See G.L. c. 223A, § 3.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85 (comparative negl.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person or entity that undertakes to provide childcare, after‑school programming, youth supervision, or similar services owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to protect children in its custody from unreasonable risk of physical harm. See G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence framework); Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 449 N.E.2d 331 (1983); Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 435 N.E.2d 339 (1982).

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 449 N.E.2d 331 (1983);
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person or entity that undertakes to provide childcare, after‑school programming, youth supervision, or similar services owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to protect children in its custody from unreasonable risk of physical harm. See G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence framework); Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 449 N.E.2d 331 (1983); Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 435 N.E.2d 339 (1982).
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The provided text is a dissent focusing solely on proximate cause—whether the defendants’ negligence caused the plaintiff’s injury. It does not discuss or contest the existence or scope of any duty to protect students (or children) from physical harm; it assumes duty and breach and disputes only causation. While the *majority* in Mullins is indeed a leading Massachusetts duty case, this excerpt, taken alone, does not provide authority for the duty proposition stated.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiffs safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 435.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person or entity that undertakes to provide childcare, after‑school programming, youth supervision, or similar services owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to protect children in its custody from unreasonable risk of physical harm. See G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence framework); Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 449 N.E.2d 331 (1983); Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 435 N.E.2d 339 (1982).
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 435.support_reasoning: The case is about premises liability to an adult trespasser injured diving into a quarry and holds that Massachusetts landowners owe no duty of reasonable care to adult trespassers, subject only to limited exceptions. It does not involve childcare, youth programs, or custodial relationships with children, nor does it articulate a general duty of reasonable care owed by entities undertaking childcare or youth supervision. Using Schofield as authority for such a childcare‑custody duty misstates its holding and context.
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 435.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 231, § 85Q, provides that a duty of reasonable care is owed to certain foreseeable child trespassers. This demonstrates the Legislature's recognition of a community consensus that landowners should exercise care for the safety of foreseeable child trespassers in certain circumstances…. An occupier of land will also be held to a duty of ordinary care to certain foreseeable child trespassers, in conformity with the statutory negligence standard imposed by G.L.c. 231, § 85Q (inserted by St. 1977, c. 259). Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 378 Mass. 177 (1979).”

Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 46.raw_text: Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 467 N.E.2d 1292 (1984).
Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 46.proposition: Defendant had a special relationship with Plaintiff’s Minor Child, akin to a school‑student or custodian‑ward relationship, that created a duty to take reasonable measures for his safety while in Defendant’s care. See Mullins, 389 Mass. at 51–53; Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 467 N.E.2d 1292 (1984).
Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 46.support_reasoning: Irwin does recognize a special relationship creating a duty, but it is between police officers and members of the motoring public when officers negligently fail to remove an intoxicated driver from the roadway. The opinion does not involve a minor child, nor any school‑student or custodian‑ward context; its special‑relationship analysis is grounded in statutory duties concerning intoxicated motorists and foreseeable risk to the public. Thus, while it supports the broader idea that a special relationship can create an affirmative duty to protect, it does not specifically support the proposition about a defendant’s custodial relationship with a plaintiff’s minor child akin to school‑student or custodian‑ward.
Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 46.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that there is a special relationship between a police officer who negligently fails to remove an intoxicated motorist from the highway, and a member of the public who suffers injury as a result of that failure. The statutes which establish police responsibilities in such circumstances evidence a legislative intent to protect both intoxicated persons and other users of the highway. As to the most crucial factor — foreseeability — the calamitous consequences to the victims of accidents caused by drunken driving are all too predictable.”

Copithorne v. Framingham Union Hosp., 40.raw_text: Copithorne v. Framingham Union Hosp., 401 Mass. 860, 860–61, 519 N.E.2d 1329 (1988);
Copithorne v. Framingham Union Hosp., 40.proposition: Children, especially younger children, are owed an enhanced degree of care commensurate with their age, size, and known vulnerabilities. See Copithorne v. Framingham Union Hosp., 401 Mass. 860, 860–61, 519 N.E.2d 1329 (1988); Lane v. Epinard, 318 Mass. 664, 63 N.E.2d 463 (1945).
Copithorne v. Framingham Union Hosp., 40.support_reasoning: The Copithorne opinion concerns a hospital’s duty and potential negligence in retaining a physician with known risks, focusing on foreseeability and proximate cause toward an adult employee-patient. It does not discuss children, age-related vulnerabilities, or any enhanced standard of care owed specifically to minors. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that younger children are owed an enhanced degree of care commensurate with their age and vulnerabilities.
Copithorne v. Framingham Union Hosp., 40.relevant_excerpt: "We think that a jury reasonably could find that the hospital owed a duty of care to Copithorne, as an employee who, in deciding to enter a doctor-patient relationship with Helfant, reasonably relied on Helfant’s good standing and reputation within the hospital community, and that the hospital violated this duty by failing to take sufficient action in response to previous allegations of Helfant’s wrongdoing."

Lane v. Epinard, 318 Mass. 664, 63 N.E.2.proposition: Children, especially younger children, are owed an enhanced degree of care commensurate with their age, size, and known vulnerabilities. See Copithorne v. Framingham Union Hosp., 401 Mass. 860, 860–61, 519 N.E.2d 1329 (1988); Lane v. Epinard, 318 Mass. 664, 63 N.E.2d 463 (1945).
Lane v. Epinard, 318 Mass. 664, 63 N.E.2.support_reasoning: Lane v. Epinard is a contract/employment case concerning the existence and breach of an oral employment agreement and related evidentiary and procedural issues. It does not involve negligence, duties of care, or any discussion of the standard of care owed to children or other vulnerable persons. Accordingly, it does not support the proposition that children are owed an enhanced degree of care commensurate with their age, size, and vulnerabilities.
Lane v. Epinard, 318 Mass. 664, 63 N.E.2.relevant_excerpt: The testimony of the plaintiff is the only evidence tending to show the existence of an oral contract of employment between herself and the decedent. She is, therefore, bound by her testimony. Head v. Morton, 302 Mass. 273, 276. Noble v. Greenbaum, 311 Mass. 722, 725. She testified that the matter of her employment as a housekeeper by the decedent was discussed in fifteen conversations between them... This testimony... was sufficient to justify a finding that the parties had entered into a contract of employment which the decedent had broken...

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 144, 849 N.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence consists of the failure to exercise the degree of care that a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 144, 849 N.E.2d 829 (2006); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696, 722 N.E.2d 971 (2000).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 144, 849 N.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the elements of negligence under Massachusetts law, including that a plaintiff must show the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care and breached that duty, which is defined by the conduct of a reasonable person. While phrased in terms of a “duty of reasonable care” rather than the exact words “reasonably prudent person,” the court’s description reflects the same standard and is consistent with the proposition cited. Thus, Jupin is properly used as authority for the general definition of negligence in Massachusetts.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 144, 849 N.relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. See J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 11.1 (3d ed. 2005)."

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696, 7.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence consists of the failure to exercise the degree of care that a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 144, 849 N.E.2d 829 (2006); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696, 722 N.E.2d 971 (2000).
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696, 7.support_reasoning: The excerpt of Glidden v. Maglio discusses the elements of a negligence claim (duty, breach, causation, damages) and focuses on plaintiffs’ failure to prove causation. It does not articulate the general definition of negligence as the failure to exercise the degree of care that a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances. Therefore, this case, at least in the provided portion, does not support the specific negligence-definition proposition for which it is cited.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696, 7.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 318.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a defendant is liable when its negligent conduct is a substantial factor in bringing about the plaintiff’s harm. See Jupin, 447 Mass. at 146; Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 318–19, 771 N.E.2d 770 (2002).
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 318.support_reasoning: The Kent opinion discusses causation and proximate cause, but it does not articulate the Massachusetts standard that a defendant is liable when its negligent conduct is a ‘substantial factor’ in bringing about the plaintiff’s harm. Instead, it frames proximate cause in terms of foreseeability and intervening/superseding causes. There is no use of the ‘substantial factor’ formulation or equivalent language, so Kent does not directly support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 318.relevant_excerpt: “[O]ne cannot be held liable for negligent conduct unless it is causally related to injury of the plaintiff. … In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. … Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct.” (Kent, 437 Mass. at 320).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B & 85..proposition: Defendant’s negligence has caused Plaintiff, acting on behalf of his son, to sustain damages compensable under Massachusetts law, including but not limited to those allowed under G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B & 85.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85..proposition: To the extent, if any, comparative negligence is alleged, Plaintiff asserts that his Minor Child exercised the degree of care to be expected of a reasonably careful child of like age, intelligence, and experience, and that any negligence attributable to him is minimal, and in any event, Plaintiff’s recovery is governed by Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85. See Colter v. Barber‑Greene Co., 403 Mass. 50, 525 N.E.2d 1305 (1988).

Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.raw_text: Colter v. Barber‑Greene Co., 403 Mass. 50, 525 N.E.2d 1305 (1988).
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.proposition: To the extent, if any, comparative negligence is alleged, Plaintiff asserts that his Minor Child exercised the degree of care to be expected of a reasonably careful child of like age, intelligence, and experience, and that any negligence attributable to him is minimal, and in any event, Plaintiff’s recovery is governed by Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85. See Colter v. Barber‑Greene Co., 403 Mass. 50, 525 N.E.2d 1305 (1988).
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses how Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, applies in negligence actions and contrasts that with the absolute bar in warranty cases. It explains that in negligence the plaintiff’s recovery is only barred if his negligence exceeds that of the defendants and otherwise is merely reduced proportionately, expressly rejecting the argument that unreasonable product use should bar negligence recovery. Although the facts involve an adult, not a child standard of care, the case clearly supports the cited point that any contributory negligence goes to comparative fault under § 85 rather than serving as a complete bar.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 85;.proposition: Plaintiff seeks all damages allowed by Massachusetts law for personal injury due to negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, and any other damages supported by the evidence and applicable law. See G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B, 85; Ferriter v. Daniel O’Connell’s Sons, Inc., 381 Mass. 507, 413 N.E.2d 690 (1980).

Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019s.raw_text: Ferriter v. Daniel O’Connell’s Sons, Inc., 381 Mass. 507, 413 N.E.2d 690 (1980).
Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019s.proposition: Plaintiff seeks all damages allowed by Massachusetts law for personal injury due to negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, and any other damages supported by the evidence and applicable law. See G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B, 85; Ferriter v. Daniel O’Connell’s Sons, Inc., 381 Mass. 507, 413 N.E.2d 690 (1980).
Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019s.case_name: Ferriter v. Daniel O'Connell's Sons, Inc.
Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019s.support_reasoning: Ferriter is a seminal case on family members’ independent tort claims (loss of consortium/society, and negligent infliction of emotional distress) and on the interaction of those claims with the Massachusetts Workers’ Compensation Act. It does not address or delineate the full range of damages recoverable by the directly injured plaintiff for personal injury (such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or loss of enjoyment of life), nor does it interpret G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B or 85. Thus it is not authority for the generic proposition about all categories of damages recoverable in a negligence personal injury action.
Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019s.relevant_excerpt: "We hold that the Ferriter children have a viable claim for loss of parental society if they can show that they are minors dependent on the parent, Michael Ferriter... We turn to the plaintiffs' claims for negligent infliction of mental distress and impaired health... We think that the present case is within the principles set out in Dziokonski.... The Workmen's Compensation Act does not bar the plaintiffs' claims for loss of consortium and society... We conclude that the King rule applies to the plaintiffs' claims for negligent infliction of mental distress, and those claims are not barred."

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19A;.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts law, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable. See G.L. c. 218, § 19A; Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.
